posts.title: Global Working Events 2017
posts.content:
If you are an International or EU student, you may find that some elements of career planning are confusing. Equally, if you are a UK student who is looking to work internationally, it can be a great idea to network and make new contacts to help advise you.

At Purple Door, we have a series of events this year that aim to help you with this. Click on an event below to see more information and to book a place through MyPurpleDoor.

Part-time Jobs Workshop for International/EU Students
Wednesday 25 January, 1.00pm-5.00pm, Purple Door
Are you an international or EU student looking for part-time work while you study? This practical session will help you understand how to find and apply for jobs and what rules apply to you.

Marketing yourself for UK Graduate Jobs as an International/EU Student
Wednesday 1 February, 2.00pm-4.00pm, Purple Door
This session will give you an awareness of how to search for graduate jobs in the UK and an understanding of the recruitment and selection process. It will also give you hands-on experience of job search and marketing yourself through CVs and application forms

Effective Global Job Search
Wednesday 8 February, 1.00pm-2.00pm, Purple Door
Are you interested in working outside the UK when you graduate, either returning to your home country or working in another country? This session will introduce you to strategies and key resources for your job search.

Visa Options with Access Tier 5 for International Students
Wednesday 22 February, 1.00pm-2.00pm, Purple Door
Are you looking to stay in the UK post your education to gain valuable UK work experience? Are you finding it difficult to find an internship simply because of your immigration status? If you have answered yes to either of these two questions, you should attend this session on Tier 5 Government Authorised Exchange by Zenia Chopra.

Enterprise Clinics for International and EU Students
Wednesday 8 March, 2.00pm-4.00pm, Purple Door
and Friday 10 March, 9.30am-11.30am, Purple Door
Are you an international or EU student interested in starting your own business in the UK? Come along to a drop-in clinic to discuss your business ideas. Enterprise clinics are available each week at these times.

Global Graduates for Global Business
Thursday 23 March, 1.00pm-3.00pm, Purple Door
Through this session you will gain an insight into the skills needed for effective global working, with input from Paul Govier (International Trade Adviser at the Department for International Trade) and Peter Riches (Managing Director of Sinoscan, a business operating in China and across Europe and North America.)

The second part of the session will involve a networking activity, where you will find out about business etiquette and expectations internationally.

We are very keen to attract international, UK and EU students for this session, enabling you to share experiences of the business context in your country.
posts.excerpt: A series of workshops and events for anyone interested in working globally

posts.title: Student Wellbeing workshops
posts.content:
Developing Mindfulness

Course dates: Wednesday 18 January and every Wednesday thereafter in term time.

Time: 2.00pm–3.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

Mindfulness is the art of directing your attention in a kindly and non- judgemental way. Studies have shown that it can be very helpful if you are prone to worrying about the future or find it hard to let go of situations or events once they have passed. The aim of the programme is to introduce you to the skill of mindfulness. It is a skill that requires practice, so we meet together to do some gentle exercises and our discussion is confined to information about those practices.

This is a rolling programme and consists of six sessions focusing on a different theme each week and repeating throughout the spring and summer terms, so you can join at any time.  Once you have completed six sessions, you’ll have the opportunity to stay on and repeat them should you wish to and if there is space. This may help you to maintain a mindfulness practice. To enrol on this course you will first need to speak briefly with a Wellbeing Service practitioner.

For more information or to book a place, email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk, phone 023 9284 3466  or call in to the Nuffield Reception.

 

From Stress to Success

Course dates: Tuesday 24 January–Tuesday  14 February (four week course)

Time: 3.30pm–5.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

This is a skills-based course designed to help students understand and manage the impact of stress more effectively. It will focus on work/life balance, time management, communication skills, assertiveness, negative thinking, problem solving and relaxation. The course uses techniques from cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), a well-proven educational psychological approach that emphasises the influence of thinking on our moods and behaviour.

To enrol for this course it is necessary to be registered with a Portsmouth GP.

For more information or to book a place, email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk, phone 023 9284 3466 or call in to the Nuffield Reception.

 

How to Beat Procrastination

Workshop date: Tuesday 24 January

Time: 2.00pm–4.30pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

Procrastination is the avoidance of a task that needs to be done – postponing until tomorrow what can be done today. If every time you sit down to do some work you find yourself diverting to something less important and repeatedly putting things off to the last minute, then this workshop could help. Participants will gain insight into why they procrastinate and how they can change their procrastinating habits. It will provide well-proven tips and strategies to help you stop putting things off and fulfil your full potential.

This workshop consists of one two-and-a-half-hour session. There will be a break with tea and coffee.

For more information or to book a place, email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk, phone 023 9284 3466 or call in to the Nuffield Reception.

 

Being a Better Friend to Yourself

Workshop date: Wednesday 25 January

Time: 1.30pm–3.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

If you find yourself being self-critical or tending to blame yourself for things for which you are not responsible, then this workshop could help. Being a better friend to yourself involves learning to have self-compassion and treating ourselves with the same care we would show a close friend. Self-compassion encourages us to be kinder and more tolerant towards ourselves, rather than getting caught up in a cycle of self-judgement. The aim of the workshop is to teach an understanding of the theory behind self-compassion and to introduce and practice some self-compassion techniques.

For more information or to book a place, email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk, phone 023 9284 3466 or call in to the Nuffield Reception.

 

A Survival Guide to Panic

Workshop date: Wednesday 25 January

Time: 3.30pm–5.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

This workshop is designed to take some of the fear out of panic attacks. By understanding what panic attacks are and why we have them, we can start to understand how to cope with them better.  Participants will learn the science of panic attacks, why it is they keep on happening and what can be done to help. This workshop is the first of three consecutive workshops focusing on aspects of anxiety – the following two are Keep Calm and Carry On and Getting a good night’s sleep.

To enrol for this workshop it is necessary to be registered with a Portsmouth GP.

For more information or to book a place, email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk, phone 023 9284 3466 or call in to the Nuffield Reception.

 

Facing Feelings

Workshop date: Tuesday 31 January

Time: 1.30pm–3.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

Developing a better understanding of the complex feelings we have and finding ways to live with and express our emotions more constructively can improve self-esteem and our relationships with family, friends, partners and in the workplace.  This workshop draws on proven techniques to improve our ability to understand, accept and manage difficult feelings, and to increase the tolerance of distress.  There will be no expectation to share personal information or experience, unless you choose to do so.

For more information or to book a place, email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk, phone 023 9284 3466 or call in to the Nuffield Reception.

 

Living Like You Mean It

Workshop date: Wednesday 1 February

Time: 1.30pm–4.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

If you could wake up tomorrow and find your life fulfilled and just as you’d like it to be, what exactly would you be doing differently?  This workshop will provide practical strategies for understanding the psychological barriers that hold you back and help you to decide what really matters to you. Drawing on evidence based approaches, participants will learn how to take effective action, despite uncertainties and challenges, and find ways to become more engaged in their own lives.

For more information or to book a place, email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk, phone 023 9284 3466 or call in to the Nuffield Reception.

 

Keep Calm and Carry On

Workshop date: Wednesday 1 February

Time: 3.30pm–5.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

This workshop focuses on how we can reduce and cope better with anxiety. If you find that you’re worrying all the time, perhaps about things that are a part of everyday life, or about things that aren’t even likely to happen, then this workshop is for you. Using cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), a well-proven educational psychological approach, participants will learn to identify and manage the triggers and symptoms of anxiety, to gain insight and to practice skills to cope more effectively. This workshop is the second of three consecutive workshops focusing on aspects of anxiety – the other two are The survival guide to panic and Getting a good night’s sleep.

To enrol for this course it is necessary to be registered with a Portsmouth GP.

For more information or to book a place, email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk, phone 023 9284 3466 or call in to the Nuffield Reception.

posts.title: Nominations needed for Enterprise Showcase 2017
posts.content:
The annual Enterprise Showcase is a fantastic opportunity for University of Portsmouth students, graduates and staff to be recognised for their entrepreneurial spirit and accomplishments.

The showcase will take place on the evening of Thursday 16 March 2017 and a number of awards will be given out.

We need your nominations for three of the categories!

The Business Start-Up of the Year Award
Students and graduates of the University of Portsmouth have a fantastic variety of innovative and creative startup businesses. We work with a few at nest, but are sure there are many student and graduate startups that deserve to be recognised for their achievements of which we are not aware. So, if you know a team or individual who has a great startup, from promoters to publishers, developers to designers, nominate them to give their business a great bit of recognition!

We will also have a prize for the winning startup – the winners will receive over £1000 in support from local businesses to help support their venture.

The Student/Graduate Entrepreneurial Spirit Award
This award is for an individual who applies an entrepreneurial spirit to everyday life. Have they shown an innovative flair during a project, do they approach activities in a different way, do they strive to make a difference to the people or situations around them?

We are looking for someone who is in tune with their passion – someone who is energised when a challenge stands in their way. And above all, they go out and they act on their ideas! They don’t have to be running a business – we are looking for students and graduates who have that spark in the way they approach their studies and experiences while at university. If you know a student who has this entrepreneurial spirit, nominate them for this award so they get recognised for their achievements.

The Staff Entrepreneurial Spirit Award
Do you have a tutor, lecturer, colleague that stands out as someone that embodies an entrepreneurial spirit? This could be for anyone employed by the University of Portsmouth who approaches their work with creativity, dedication and drive.

Nominate them for this award so they can be recognised for their hard work!

Please note: Nominations must be for a University of Portsmouth student, recent graduate or member of staff. You may nominate yourself.
posts.excerpt: The annual Enterprise Showcase is a fantastic chance for University of Portsmouth students, graduates and staff to be recognised for their entrepreneurial spirit and accomplishments.

posts.title: National Student Survey 2017 is now open
posts.title_plain: National Student Survey 2017 is now open
posts.content:
On Monday 16 January Ipsos MORI will email final-year undergraduate students a link to the National Student Survey (NSS), which needs to be completed by 30 April.

The NSS is an annual survey of final-year undergraduate students across the UK. Last year over 300,000 students took part nationally, including over 3,500 from Portsmouth. The results of that survey are published on the Unistats website.

Eligible students can access the survey via a link in the invitation email from Ipsos MORI, through a link from their Moodle account, or by going online to complete the survey directly at www.thestudentsurvey.com.

The results of the NSS are very important to the University and the Students’ Union. Student feedback is used to inform how we improve our courses, invest in facilities and develop the whole student experience.

Just as existing students may have benefited from feedback provided by past students, feedback can help prospective students when choosing which institution to go to and what course to study.

The NSS takes no longer than ten minutes complete and is mobile phone friendly. All University of Portsmouth students who participate will have the chance to win one of 27 prizes from the University, which includes VIP graduation packages, £250 One4All gift cards and weekend tickets for the Victorious Festival.

More information about the NSS is available on MyPort and www.thestudentsurvey.com.

posts.title: University arrangements in case of snow
posts.title_plain: University arrangements in case of snow
posts.content:
There are mixed reports of the potential for snow over the next few days.

If the campus is affected significantly by snow we will provide updates via email and on the UoP News staff and students pages. Please also check local travel information.

Schools and departments are advised to contact students via email with any changes to the timetable.

Staff in outlying areas affected by snow should contact their line manager to discuss working from home or other arrangements. If, at any point, staff cannot make it to work or are delayed they should contact their line manager as soon as they can by phone.

posts.title: Back after Christmas reminder – get vaccinated against meningitis and septicaemia
posts.title_plain: Back after Christmas reminder – get vaccinated against meningitis and septicaemia
posts.content:
Getting vaccinated against meningitis and septicaemia protects you and will help reduce the spread of the deadly infection. Your can also look after one another by knowing the signs and symptoms to look out for.

Public Health England figures showed that less than a third (29.5%) of all young people leaving school last summer had been immunised with the Men ACWY vaccine by the end of October. There has been a year-on-year increase in cases of Men W across all age groups – from 22 cases in 2009/10 to 210 cases in 2015/16. As cases have increased, the total number of related deaths has also risen, with 1 in 8 people with MenW disease dying from the infection.

New students are at a higher risk of meningococcal disease, mixing closely with large numbers of new people, some of whom will unknowingly be carrying the bacteria, without any signs or symptoms, enabling it to spread

If you haven’t already register with a GP in Portsmouth  to get your vaccine.

For more information search Myport for Meningitis.

posts.title: University Technical College Portsmouth – applications for autumn 2017 close next week
posts.title_plain: University Technical College Portsmouth – applications for autumn 2017 close next week
posts.content:
The University is the lead sponsor in the establishment of the University Technical College Portsmouth (UTC Portsmouth), in Hilsea, which opens its doors in September 2017.

Up to 600 pupils, aged 14–19, will specialise in advanced manufacturing, science, technology, engineering or maths, alongside studying core GCSE subjects and participating in a wide range of sporting and enrichment activities. UTC Portsmouth will provide this specialised training to address workforce shortages in these areas across the Solent Region.

The UTC is working with the University and employers, including the Royal Navy, BAE Systems, Airbus, Land Rover BAR and NATS to develop the curriculum and pupil opportunities preparing pupils to be ‘work ready’ upon leaving. UTC Portsmouth joins sixty existing UTCs operating across England.

Ciaran O’Dowda, UTC Portsmouth Principal

Ciaran O’Dowda, the UTC Portsmouth Principal said: ‘I am sure that you have heard about this brand new college as the University of Portsmouth has been a vital partner in its creation.

‘If you have a son or daughter, currently in Year 11 of secondary school, you may wish to seriously consider UTC Portsmouth for their post-16 studies. Our college is appealing to students who wish to continue with a largely STEM-based education (Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths) with tangible links to employment and higher education after college.’

Year 12 applications close on 15 January 2017. Applications can be made online in five minutes. Limited spaces available.

For more information, please visit www.utcportsmouth.org.
posts.excerpt: Year 12 applications for the STEM college’s September intake close on 15 January 2017 – applying online takes five minutes.

posts.title: Make your bike road safe: Dr Bike events
posts.title_plain: Make your bike road safe: Dr Bike events
posts.content:
Dr Bike events will be held at the University during January.

At the sessions, a team of experienced bike mechanics will check everything on your bike from wheels to gears, and brakes to lights. Any minor adjustments or basic repairs can be made there and then. If it can’t be fixed immediately, you will be informed exactly what needs doing and the approximate cost.

The Bike Doctor clinics will take place outside Dennis Sciama Building on the following dates:

  • Thursday 12 January, 10.30am–2.30pm
  • Thursday 9 February, 10.30am–2.30pm
  • Thursday 9 March, 10.30am–2.30pm

There is no need to book.

It’s important to keep your bike in good working order. Make sure that:

• it is the correct size for comfort and safety
• both tyres are inflated properly and have good tread
• the chain is oiled and properly adjusted
• all brakes work and the brake pads aren’t worn
• reflectors and lights are fitted and working – all bikes must have a rear reflector and pedal reflectors fitted by law, and working front and rear lights during the hours of darkness, so remember to keep them clean!
posts.excerpt: At the Bike Doctor sessions a team of experienced bike mechanics will check everything on your bike from wheels to gears, and brakes to lights.
